sentence.617: TA575 Uses ‘Squid Game’ Lures to Distribute Dridex malware
sentence.618: Proofpoint identified the large cybercrime actor TA575 distributing Dridex malware using [Squid Game](https://www.netflix.com/title/81040344) lures.
sentence.619: The threat actor is purporting to be entities associated with the Netflix global phenomenon using emails enticing targets to get early access to a new season of Squid Game or to become a part of the TV show casting.
sentence.620: On October 27, 2021, Proofpoint observed thousands of emails targeting all industries primarily in the United States.
sentence.621: *Figure 1: Netflix Squid Game email lure inviting customers to get early access to a new season*
sentence.622: *Figure 2: Netflix Squid Game email lure soliciting actors and background talent to apply to be on the show or show commercials*
sentence.623: The emails tell the victim to fill out either an attached document to get early access to the new season of the show or a talent form to become part of the background casting.
sentence.624: The attachments are Excel documents with macros that, if enabled, will download the Dridex banking trojan affiliate id “22203” from Discord URLs.
sentence.625: Dridex is a prolific banking trojan distributed by multiple affiliates that can lead to data theft and installation of follow-on malware such as ransomware.
sentence.626: *Figure 3: One of the several Excel attachment lures observed in this campaign*
sentence.627: TA575 is a Dridex affiliate tracked by Proofpoint since late 2020.
sentence.628: This group distributes malware via malicious URLs, Microsoft Office attachments, and password-protected files.
sentence.629: On average, TA575 sends thousands of emails per campaign impacting hundreds of organizations.
sentence.630: TA575 also uses the Discord content delivery network (CDN) to host and distribute Dridex.
sentence.631: Discord, a communications platform with consumer and enterprise uses, is an increasingly popular malware hosting service for cybercriminals.
sentence.632: TA575 themes generally include invoicing and payments, but occasionally include popular news, events, and cultural references.
sentence.633: Cybercriminal threat actors in general have pounced on Squid Game as a popular lure and [malware theme](https://www.techrepublic.com/article/you-definitely-dont-want-to-play-squid-game-themed-malware-is-here/).
sentence.634: This makes sense; as Squid Game is Netflix’s “[biggest ever](https://www.cnn.com/2021/10/12/media/squid-game-netflix-viewership/index.html)” series, the pool of potential victims who would inadvertently interact with malicious content associated with it is higher than a general lure theme.
sentence.635: TA575 is betting the invitation to be part of the upcoming season will entice more users to interact with the malicious Microsoft Excel file.
sentence.636: Proofpoint observed the following indicators of compromise:
sentence.641: Triple Threat: North Korea-Aligned TA406 Scams, Spies, and Steals
sentence.642: [**![](/sites/default/files/pdficon.png) Download full report (PDF)**](/us/resources/threat-reports/triple-threat-north-korea-aligned-ta406-scams-spies-and-steals "Triple Threat: North Korea Aligned TA406 Scams, Spies, and Steals")
sentence.643: * Throughout 2021, the North Korea-aligned threat actor TA406 conducted frequent credential theft campaigns targeting research, education, government, media and other organizations.
sentence.644: * Proofpoint considers TA406 to be one of several actors that make up the activity publicly tracked as Kimsuky, Thallium and Konni Group.
sentence.645: * TA406 doesn’t usually employ [malware](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/malware) in campaigns.
sentence.646: However, two notable 2021 campaigns attributed to this group attempted to distribute malware that could be used for information gathering.
sentence.647: * TA406 engages in espionage, cyber crime and sextortion.
sentence.648: Throughout 2021, Proofpoint has tracked ongoing credential theft campaigns from TA406, an actor associated with the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (DPRK).
sentence.649: Our analysts have tracked TA406 campaigns targeting customers since 2018, but the threat actor’s campaigns remained low in volume until the beginning of January 2021.
sentence.650: From January through June 2021, Proofpoint observed almost weekly campaigns targeting foreign policy experts, journalists and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs).
sentence.651: In this report, we describe in detail many of the campaigns and behaviors associated with an actor operating on behalf of the North Korean government: TA406.
sentence.652: We begin by explaining how TA406 is associated with Kimsuky, a threat actor name broadly tracked by the threat intelligence community.
sentence.653: We then elaborate on how Proofpoint tracks the activity of Kimsuky as three separate threat actors—TA406, TA408 and TA427.
sentence.654: Also, we detail the differences between these actors, based on Proofpoint’s visibility.
sentence.655: This report also examines campaign timing and targeting by TA406, and it provides a look into how TA406 conducts [phishing](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/phishing) campaigns, including the tools and services used.
sentence.656: TA406 employs both malware and credential harvesting in espionage and information-gathering campaigns.
sentence.657: This report details several examples of each, including different types of credential collection and two implants used by TA406 that haven’t been discussed before in open-source reporting.
sentence.658: And finally, like all other North Korean state-sponsored actors that Proofpoint tracks, we provide evidence that TA406 conducts financially motivated campaigns, including the targeting of cryptocurrency and sextortion.
sentence.661: **To read more, [download the full report](/us/resources/threat-reports/triple-threat-north-korea-aligned-ta406-scams-spies-and-steals "Triple Threat: North Korea Aligned TA406 Scams, Spies, and Steals")[.](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/resources/threat-reports/triple-threat-north-korea-aligned-ta406-scams-spies-and-steals)**
sentence.662: High Volume German Phishing Campaign Aims to Steal Banking Credentials
sentence.663: Proofpoint researchers identified an increase in credential phishing campaigns attempting to steal German banking credentials.
sentence.664: Since the end of August 2021, Proofpoint researchers observed multiple high-volume campaigns leveraging customized, actor-owned landing pages spoofing major German banks, notably Volksbank and Sparkasse.
sentence.665: The campaigns targeted multiple industries, specifically German companies and employees of foreign entities located in Germany.
sentence.666: Each campaign included tens of thousands of messages impacting hundreds of organizations.
sentence.667: The phishing emails purport to be account administration information and contain links or QR codes that direct the victim to a geo-fenced credential harvesting page.
sentence.668: *Figure 1: Email samples containing QR code (left) and link to spoofed website (right).*
sentence.669: The threat actor has used multiple URL redirection techniques to deliver the malicious links.
sentence.670: In several observed campaigns, the threat actor leveraged compromised Wordpress websites to redirect users to the phishing landing pages.
sentence.671: Abusing Wordpress plugins and websites running Wordpress software is a [common technique](https://portswigger.net/daily-swig/url-redirect-malware-infects-thousands-of-wordpress-sites) used by threat actors to distribute malicious links for phishing and malware attacks.
sentence.672: Additionally, researchers observed both Feedproxy URLs and QR codes used to redirect to the phishing pages.
sentence.673: The threat actor leverages geo-fencing techniques to ensure only users in Germany are redirected to the phishing page.
sentence.674: Proofpoint assesses with high confidence the threat actors are conducting IP geolocation checks to identify a target’s location.
sentence.675: If they are not in Germany, the user is directed to a clone of a website purporting to be tourist information for the Rhine Tower in Dusseldorf, Germany.
sentence.676: If a user is in Germany, they will be directed to a webpage masquerading as a legitimate banking website.
sentence.677: The user is encouraged to choose their Branch location and click “Login” to be directed to the credential capture page, spoofing the legitimate banking site.
sentence.678: For example, the Sparkasse credential phishing URLs often start with “spk-” while Volksbank clones begin with “vr-”.
sentence.679: Typically, the actor uses the domain registrar REG.RU, with domains hosted via AliCloud (Germany) GmbH.
sentence.680: The actor/s is/are consistently registering new domains in the identified URL structure and the campaigns are ongoing.
sentence.681: Proofpoint is not able to attribute this campaign to a known threat group.
sentence.682: Domain registration indicates this actor may have been focused on targeting users of Spanish banks earlier this year.
sentence.683: Cybercriminal threat actors associated with banking credential theft and fraudulent financial activity tend to be opportunistic and target large numbers of victims.
sentence.684: This is typically referred to as “spray and pray” activity, sending mass email campaigns in the hopes some of the targeted individuals fall for their scams.
sentence.685: * At the same time, assume that users will eventually click some threats.
sentence.686: Find a solution that spots and blocks inbound email threats targeting employees before they reach the inbox.
sentence.687: Your solution should analyze both external and internal email—attackers may use compromised accounts to trick users within the same organization.
sentence.688: University Targeted Credential Phishing Campaigns Use COVID-19, Omicron Themes
sentence.689: Proofpoint researchers have identified an increase in email threats targeting mostly North American universities attempting to steal university login credentials.
sentence.690: Proofpoint observed COVID-19 themes impacting education institutions throughout the pandemic, but consistent, targeted credential theft campaigns using such lures targeting universities began in October 2021.
sentence.691: Following the announcement of the new [Omicron](https://www.who.int/news/item/26-11-2021-classification-of-omicron-(b.1.1.529)-sars-cov-2-variant-of-concern) variant in late November, the threat actors began leveraging the new variant in credential theft campaigns.
sentence.692: Threat actors continue to use COVID-19 theme lures in campaigns targeting multiple industries and geographic areas.
sentence.693: The threats specifically targeting universities is interesting due to the specificity in targeting and effort to mimic legitimate login portals.
sentence.694: We expect more threat actors will adopt COVID-19 themes given the introduction of the Omicron variant.
sentence.695: This assessment is based on previously [published research](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/delta-variant-spreads-covid-19-themes-make-resurgence-email-threats) that identified COVID-19 themes making a resurgence in email campaigns
sentence.696: The COVID-19 themed campaigns including Omicron variant lures include thousands of messages targeted to dozens of universities in North America.
sentence.697: The [phishing emails](/us/threat-reference/phishing "Phishing") contain attachments or URLs for pages intended to harvest credentials for university accounts.
sentence.698: The landing pages typically imitate the university’s official login portal, although some campaigns feature generic Office 365 login portals.
sentence.699: In some cases, such as the Omicron variant lures, victims are redirected to a legitimate university communication after credentials are harvested.
sentence.700: Proofpoint observed this threat actor pivot from Delta variant themed email lures to Omicron themes following the announcement of the new variant.
sentence.701: Emails with URLs use subjects such as:
sentence.702: With a link to a spoofed landing page such as:
sentence.703: *Figure 1: Spoofed login page for the University of Central Missouri.*
sentence.704: Messages distributing attachments included subject lines such as “Covid Test”.
sentence.706: *Figure 2: HTM attachment leading to a credential capture webpage.*
sentence.707: *Figure 3: Credential theft webpage spoofing Vanderbilt University.*
sentence.708: Proofpoint has identified multiple threat clusters using COVID-19 themes to target universities using different tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs).
sentence.709: In addition to multiple delivery methods – Proofpoint has observed both URL and attachments in campaigns – activity clusters use different sender and hosting methods to distribute credential theft campaigns.
sentence.710: In the Omicron variant campaign, threat actors leverage actor-controlled infrastructure to host credential theft webpages using similar domain naming patterns.
sentence.711: Attachment-based campaigns have leveraged legitimate but compromised WordPress websites to host credential capture webpages, including:
sentence.712: In some campaigns, threat actors attempted to steal [multifactor authentication (MFA)](/us/threat-reference/multifactor-authentication "Multifactor Authentication") credentials, spoofing MFA providers such as Duo. Stealing MFA tokens enables the attacker to bypass the second layer of security designed to keep out threat actors who already know a victim’s username and password.
sentence.714: *Figure 4: Duo MFA credential theft landing page.*
sentence.715: While many messages are sent via spoofed senders, Proofpoint has observed threat actors leveraging legitimate, compromised university accounts to send COVID-19 themed threats.
sentence.716: It is likely the threat actors are stealing credentials from universities and using compromised mailboxes to send the same threats to other universities.
sentence.717: Proofpoint does not attribute this activity to a known actor or threat group, and the ultimate objective of the threat actors is currently unknown.
sentence.718: That Holiday Feelin’: TA575 Brings the Warm and Fuzzies with Year-end, Festive Lures
sentence.719: The threat actor tracked by Proofpoint as TA575 has kicked off the festive season with holiday-themed lures and is getting a head start on tax season in their latest high-volume campaigns.
sentence.720: Proofpoint researchers have observed a range of email subjects from "Black firday and Cyber Monday Survey Scam alert" to "Christmas tips: Preparing for Holydays," "Holiday Survey Threats beware," and even "Winter lifehacks: Cutest Tax Credit.
sentence.721: The ultimate intent of the campaigns is to lure potential victims into downloading the Dridex banking trojan.
sentence.722: Dridex, which is a prolific piece of malware distributed by multiple affiliates, can lead to theft of personally identifiable information and installation of secondary payloads such as [ransomware](/us/threat-reference/ransomware "Ransomware").
sentence.723: The campaigns have impacted numerous industries, such as education, manufacturing, local government, insurance, and finance in the United States—a typical geographic focus of TA575.
sentence.724: TA575 began this year's spate of holiday campaigns on November 24, 2021.
sentence.725: The emails delivered malicious Microsoft Excel file attachments that, if opened, used XL4 macros to download and execute Dridex affiliate id "22201" from a URL.
sentence.726: A November 29, 2021 campaign shifted to pulling Dridex affiliate id "22202" from Discord URLs. TA575 has used the Discord content delivery network (CDN) to host and distribute the banking trojan in other [campaigns](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/ta575-uses-squid-game-lures-distribute-dridex-malware) this year.
sentence.727: TA575's November 2021 campaigns veered away from the more wholesome and, at times, religious themes used by the group in 2020 to play on potential victims' desires for discounts and fears over being scammed this holiday season.
sentence.729: Prepare for the silly season | Black Friday Amazon coupon #40868249
sentence.730: In December 2021, TA575 started to use both Microsoft Excel and Word attachments to deliver Dridex via Discord URLs, HTA files, and remote template.
sentence.731: The campaign used both the Dridex affiliate id "22201" and "22204.
sentence.732: In some cases, the emails combined themes, using both the approaching holidays and the coming new year with US tax filing preparation and spoofing popular do-it-yourself tax services as seen in Figure 2.
sentence.733: *Figure 2. December 1, 2021 email spoofing a tax service.*
sentence.734: TA575, like other threat actors, is adept at using current events-based lures to take advantage of people being more interested in the topic than keeping their guard up from nefarious schemes.
sentence.735: During the holiday season, users become desensitized to receiving numerous advertising links for shopping deals and the like and may not think twice about opening a dangerous file or clicking a suspicious link.
sentence.746: TinyNuke Banking Malware Targets French Entities
sentence.747: * Proofpoint researchers identified ongoing activity from the banking malware TinyNuke.
sentence.748: * The activity nearly exclusively targets French entities and organizations with operations in France.
sentence.749: * The new activity demonstrates a re-emergence of the malware specifically targeting French users that peaked in popularity in 2018.
sentence.750: Proofpoint identified multiple recent campaigns leveraging invoice-themed lures to distribute the uncommonly observed TinyNuke malware.
sentence.751: The campaigns use French language lures with invoice or other financial themes, and almost exclusively target French entities and companies with operations in France.
sentence.752: TinyNuke is a banking trojan that first appeared in Proofpoint data in 2017 targeting French companies.
sentence.753: It is similar to the notorious banking trojan Zeus, which has [many variants](/us/blog/threat-insight/zloader-loads-again-new-zloader-variant-returns "ZLoader Loads Again: New ZLoader Variant Returns") with identical functionality.
sentence.754: TinyNuke can be used to steal credentials and other private information and can be used to enable follow-on [malware attacks](/us/threat-reference/malware "Malware").
sentence.755: The author initially [released](https://github.com/aainz/TinyNuke) the code on GitHub in 2017, and although the original repo is no longer available, other open-source versions of the malware exist.
sentence.756: Proofpoint observed dozens of TinyNuke campaigns targeting French entities in 2018.
sentence.757: After only observing a handful of TinyNuke campaigns in 2019 and 2020, Proofpoint observed TinyNuke reappear in January 2021 in one campaign distributing around 2,000 emails.
sentence.758: In November, Proofpoint identified multiple TinyNuke campaigns distributing around 2,500 messages and impacting hundreds of customers.
sentence.759: ![Email lure with link leading to the download of TinyNuke.](/sites/default/files/inline-images/Screen%20Shot%202021-12-08%20at%201.55.44%20PM.png)
sentence.760: *Figure 1: Email lure with link leading to the download of TinyNuke.*
sentence.761: These messages contain URLs that lead to the download of a compressed executable responsible for installing TinyNuke.
sentence.762: Proofpoint first observed TinyNuke in 2017 used as a second-stage payload in a Zeus banking trojan campaign targeting French entities.
sentence.763: Its use peaked in 2018 before all but disappearing in Proofpoint data in 2019 and 2020.
sentence.766: Proofpoint has observed three times as many TinyNuke campaigns in 2021 as the two previous years combined.
sentence.767: But while threat actors have conducted more campaigns this year, they are distributing fewer messages compared to previous years.
sentence.770: Though the number of 2021 campaigns is less than 2018, TinyNuke’s reappearance and consistent targeting of French organizations is striking, suggesting it is a re-emerging threat in the French cybercrime threat landscape.
sentence.771: Proofpoint assesses there are at least two distinct activity sets using TinyNuke based on different lure themes, payload deployment, and command and control (C2) infrastructure.
sentence.772: Specifically, one intrusion set associated with the initial TinyNuke actors uses Tor for C2 since 2018, while commodity actors typically leverage clear web C2.
sentence.773: Open source [reporting suggests](https://blog.heat-miser.net/posts/tinynuke/) the malware version using Tor which Proofpoint has observed with continued regularity is not publicly available, and likely used only by the original TinyNuke threat actors.
sentence.774: The following analysis focuses on the most frequently observed activity set responsible for most of the TinyNuke campaigns in 2021.
sentence.776: In the recently observed campaigns, messages are sent with URLs that lead to ZIP files.
sentence.777: The ZIP files contain a JavaScript file (e.g. Facture-78224UDJ2021.js) which is invoked by the Microsoft Windows native binary wscript.
sentence.778: PowerShell is then executed and leverages the Start-BitsTransfer cmdlet to download another ZIP file (e.g. putty.zip) which contains the TinyNuke PE file.
sentence.781: The actor generally uses legitimate, but compromised, websites to host the payload URL.
sentence.782: The websites are typically French language, and do not share a common theme.
sentence.783: The following binaries are dropped to disk and executed.
sentence.784: In the recently observed campaigns, C2 communications occur via Tor. For example: fizi4aqe7hpsts3r[.]onion/hci/client[.]php
sentence.785: Proofpoint researchers observed the string "nikoumouk" sent to the C2 server for an unknown purpose.
sentence.786: According to information sharing partners and open-source information, the actors previously used that string in C2 communications in previous campaigns since 2018.
sentence.787: The string is an insult in popular Arabic, mainly used in French speaking suburbs in Europe.
sentence.788: Persistence is achieved by adding an entry in the registry under the following location.
sentence.790: Once installed, the TinyNuke loader can be used for data and credential theft with formgrabbing and webinject capabilities for Firefox, Internet Explorer, and Chrome, and to install follow on payloads.
sentence.791: Proofpoint identified TinyNuke infrastructure used in campaigns in 2018 overlapped with [PyLocky ransomware attacks](https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/18/i/a-closer-look-at-the-locky-poser-pylocky-ransomware.html) first reported that year.
sentence.792: However, Proofpoint has not observed ransomware activity associated with TinyNuke in subsequent campaigns.
sentence.793: Public reporting [associates](https://krebsonsecurity.com/2019/12/nuclear-bot-author-arrested-in-sextortion-case/) the original TinyNuke author with an individual charged in a French sextortion case, and was imprisoned before [reportedly](https://blog.heat-miser.net/posts/tinynuke/) being released under legal supervision in 2020 during a spike in the COVID pandemic.
sentence.794: In 2017, the accused individual previously claimed to be the original author of TinyNuke in an [interview](https://krebsonsecurity.com/2017/04/self-proclaimed-nuclear-bot-author-weighs-u-s-job-offer/) with the journalist Brian Krebs.
sentence.795: TinyNuke actors have also reportedly [taunted](https://blog.heat-miser.net/posts/tinynuke/) and harassed security researchers investigating TinyNuke activity.
sentence.796: Proofpoint does not associate TinyNuke with a known threat actor or group.
sentence.797: The malware is publicly available and likely used by multiple threat actors, however Proofpoint assesses with high confidence at least some of the original threat actors distributing TinyNuke in 2018 continue to use it.
sentence.798: TinyNuke has re-emerged as a threat to French organizations, and entities with operations in France.
sentence.799: Of note, in most of the recent campaigns the actor has stayed consistent with using URLs to ZIP files and the continued use of Tor for C2 communications.

sentence.834: * As multi-factor authentication becomes a standard security practice, phish kits are evolving with the times to steal these tokens and bypass this trusted layer of security.
sentence.835: * Threat actors are using phish kits that leverage transparent reverse proxy, which enables them to man-in-the-middle (MitM) a browser session and steal credentials and session cookies in real-time.
sentence.836: * It is likely that more threat actors will turn to these MitM phish kits, making security increasingly difficult for defenders.
sentence.837: Since the inclusion of the first password in the [Compatible Time-Sharing System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Password#History) at MIT in 1961, people have been cognizant of information security.
sentence.838: While multi-factor authentication (MFA) did not enter the scene until years later in 1986 with the first RSA tokens, it has recently seen widespread adoption in the consumer space.
sentence.839: According to MFA digital authenticator company Duo's annual [State of the Auth Report](https://duo.com/blog/the-2021-state-of-the-auth-report-2fa-climbs-password-managers-biometrics-trend) 78% of respondents have used two/multi-factor authentication (2FA/MFA) in 2021 compared to just 28% in 2017.
sentence.840: While many companies like Duo and RSA have helped make MFA more ubiquitous and user-friendly, threat actors have not been resting on their laurels, choosing to target MFA as well as looking for ways to bypass MFA with evolving phishing kits.
sentence.841: ![Duo State of the Auth Report 2021 shows increase in MFA usage.](/sites/default/files/inline-images/Screen%20Shot%202022-02-01%20at%2011.17.28%20AM.png)
sentence.842: *Figure 1. Duo State of the Auth Report 2021 shows increase in MFA usage.*
sentence.844: Phishing kits are software developed to aid threat actors in harvesting credentials and quickly capitalizing on them.
sentence.845: Proofpoint threat researchers see numerous MFA phishing kits ranging from simple open-source kits with human readable code and no-frills functionality to sophisticated kits utilizing numerous layers of obfuscation and built-in modules that allow for stealing usernames, passwords, MFA tokens, social security numbers and credit card numbers.
sentence.846: At their core these kits are using the same techniques for harvesting credentials as the traditional kits that steal only usernames and passwords.
sentence.847: ![Simple phishing kit utilizing an open directory ](/sites/default/files/inline-images/Screen%20Shot%202022-02-01%20at%2011.19.05%20AM.png)
sentence.848: *Figure 2. Simple phishing kit utilizing an open directory with credentials stored on the same webserver as the kit.*
sentence.849: In recent years, Proofpoint researchers have observed the emergence of a new type of kit that does not rely on recreating a target website.
sentence.850: Instead, these kits use a [transparent reverse proxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_proxy#:~:text=In%20computer%20networks%2C%20a%20reverse,mainly%20used%20to%20balance%20load. to present the actual website to the victim.
sentence.851: Therefore, presenting the actual site instead of a facsimile greatly enhances the illusion an individual is logging in safely.
sentence.852: Another advantage of the reverse proxy is that it allows the threat actor to man-in-the-middle (MitM) a session and capture not only the usernames and passwords in real-time, but also the session cookie.
sentence.855: The session cookie (see Figure 4) can then be used by the threat actor to gain access to the targeted account without the need for a username, password, or MFA token.
sentence.858: Proofpoint researchers have noted a small increase in the use of these phish kits and anticipate greater adoption by threat actors as MFA forces them to adapt.
sentence.859: Specifically, Proofpoint has noted three transparent reverse proxy kits emerging on the scene.
sentence.861: Modlishka: A Polish security researcher Piotr Duszyński developed Modliska and released it in December 2018 on github.com.
sentence.862: This relatively simple tool allows phishing one site at a time, sports a command line interface, and provides the threat actor with a handy GUI to retrieve the credentials and session information (see Figure 5).
sentence.863: Modlishka also integrates Let’s Encrypt so it can make the fake domain landing page just a bit more believable by encrypting the traffic and providing the little padlock in the web bar.
sentence.864: While Modlishka may not be as advanced as the other two kits discussed later in this blog, it is still capable of harvesting a victim’s session even when tech like Duo’s push notification [authenticator is used](https://commons.lib.jmu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1004&context=masters202029).
sentence.865: Muraena/Necrobrowser: Muraena/Necrobrowser is a two-part tool for phishing session cookies, credentials, and much more.
sentence.866: Once the victim's credentials and session cookie has been harvested by the threat actor, they can deploy Necrobrowser.
sentence.867: Necrobrowser is a headless browser, which is a browser without a graphical user interface used for automation, that leverages the stolen session cookies to log into the target site and do things such as change passwords, disable Google Workspace notifications, dump emails, change SSH session keys in GitHub, and download all code repositories.
sentence.868: Evilginx2: Evilginx2 is an easy to use, transparent reverse proxy written in Golang by security researcher and developer Kuba Gretzky (Figure 6).
sentence.869: Evilginx2 allows you to configure a custom subdomain and landing page URL for each as well.
sentence.870: The kit comes with several pre-installed “phishlets,” but more can be created and added easily.
sentence.871: Once a victim clicks on the malicious link, they are taken to a secure page with assets being displayed exactly how they are on the target site.
sentence.872: After they log in, the credentials, including MFA codes, and session cookie are sent to the server in real-time and the victim is either redirected to a different page or allowed to continue through to the page.
sentence.873: The threat actor is then able to use the stolen session cookie to log in as the victim where they can take multiple actions like changing the password, copying data, or pretending to be the victim.
sentence.876: In their [recent paper](https://catching-transparent-phish.github.io/catching_transparent_phish.pdf), researchers from Stony Brook University and Palo Alto Networks (Kondracki et al) took a deep dive into MitM phishing kits and discovered that MitM phishing pages represent an industry blind spot.
sentence.877: The researchers developed a machine learning tool called Phoca to scan suspected phishing pages and try to determine if they were using a transparent reverse proxy to MitM credentials.
sentence.878: They were able to identify over 1200 MitM phishing sites.
sentence.879: In addition to this, they found that standard phishing sites had a lifespan of just under 24 hours whereas MitM phishing sites lasted longer, and 15% had a lifespan greater than 20 days.
sentence.880: As recently as the end of January 2021, Proofpoint researchers identified a MitM reverse proxy site that was active for more than 72 hours.
sentence.882: *Figure 7. MitM O365 page.(domain redacted as without the full path it redirects to NSFW content)*
sentence.883: In May 2021, Google discussed in a [blog post](https://blog.google/technology/safety-security/a-simpler-and-safer-future-without-passwords/) that they would soon start to require MFA when logging into a Google account sometime in late 2021 or early 2022 (it would still be optional for Google Workspace customers).
sentence.884: As more companies follow Google’s lead and start requiring MFA, threat actors will rapidly move to solutions like these MitM kits.
sentence.885: How DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH) has Changed the Threat Landscape For Companies
sentence.886: DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH) protocol is now offered and in some instances standard, in major Internet browsers.
sentence.887: DoH provides the benefit of communicating DNS information over a secure HTTPS connection in an encrypted manner.
sentence.890: In 2017, [the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) proposed a new standard](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8484) for the Internet protocol named DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH).
sentence.891: DoH is meant as a secure alternative to the existing standard Domain Name System (DNS) protocol for sharing IP addresses.
sentence.892: The DoH protocol communicates DNS information over a secure HTTPS connection in an encrypted manner.
sentence.893: However, DoH does not provide end-to-end security and only protects communications while in transit.
sentence.894: The primary benefit of DoH is that it encrypts all DNS information, whereas DNS is currently sent in plain text over HTTP.
sentence.895: Therefore, DoH offers more privacy and data protection, especially from Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks (e.g. DNS hijacking and spoofing) that would allow for snooping and manipulation of the DNS information.
sentence.896: Google Chrome and Mozilla Firefox were early adopters, having rolled out DoH in their respective browsers in late 2019.
sentence.897: Malware authors have rushed to exploit DoH in their attack operations because a victim’s DNS traffic will now often bypass organizational DNS infrastructure, circumventing security detection and protection systems.
sentence.898: At the time of initial rollout in 2019, we assessed it would be very likely that more malware families would begin to incorporate DoH into their operations, as well as new data-exfiltration tools leveraging DoH as C2.
sentence.899: In fact, in July 2020 Researchers from Kaspersky reported on [Iran-linked threat actor group *APT34*](https://quointelligence.eu/2020/12/cyber-security-trends-in-2021/) (also known as *OilRig*) evolving tactics using DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH) as a channel for data exfiltration through an open-source tool.
sentence.900: The evolution was first discovered in May 2020, when the threat actor group used the publicly available tool DNSExfiltrator2 to move data laterally through the internal network and attempted to exfiltrate to an attacker-controlled system.
sentence.901: Additionally, in August and November 2020, [QuoIntelligence detected targeted campaigns that share similarities to the threat actor we previously dubbed ReconHellcat.](https://quointelligence.eu/2020/09/apt28-zebrocy-malware-campaign-nato-theme/) Among the state-of-the-art techniques leveraged by ReconHellcat, the group also used Cloudflare Workers as a C2 communication interface and DoH as their name resolution channel.
sentence.903: With the introduction of DoH by Internet browsers and operating systems, companies are often unable to detect compromised hosts based on DNS traffic analysis.
sentence.904: * **Bypassed security measures**: [According to Qihoo 360 researchers](https://blog.netlab.360.com/an-analysis-of-godlua-backdoor-en/), the first malware spotted in the wild using DoH was employed by threat actors operating a new backdoor malware dubbed Godlua.
sentence.905: Shortly thereafter, [ProofPoint researchers](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-insight/post/psixbot-now-using-google-dns-over-https-and-possible-new-sexploitation-module) detailed a new variant of the PsiXBot malware incorporating Google’s DoH service.
sentence.906: Malware authors implement DoH in their attack operations because a victim’s DNS traffic will mostly bypass the organization’s DNS infrastructure, circumventing security protections.
sentence.907: * **Incompatibility with established regulation:** The rapid adaption of DoH could negatively affect the ability of governments to monitor terrorist threats or to censor and ban other illegal content.
sentence.908: For example, [the UK’s 2016 Investigatory Powers Act](https://services.parliament.uk/bills/2015-16/investigatorypowers.html) requires ISPs to store 12-month web visit history for its citizens, achieved using now often-encrypted DNS requests.
sentence.909: + In April 2020, chief information officers of agencies within the US Government were recommended to disable third party encrypted DNS services.
sentence.910: In January 2021, [the US National Security Agency (NSA) released an updated guideline](https://media.defense.gov/2021/Jan/14/2002564889/-1/-1/0/CSI_ADOPTING_ENCRYPTED_DNS_U_OO_102904_21.PDF)  for companies adopting DoH in enterprise environments.
sentence.911: The following tables of high- and medium-risk threats and remedial actions related to the DoH protocol in enterprise networks has been updated to include a summary of these latest recommendations.
sentence.912: ###### Table 1: High-risk threats and remedial actions related to the DoH protocol in enterprise networks by QuoIntelligence
sentence.913: ###### Table 2: Medium-risk threats and remedial actions related to the DoH protocol in enterprise networks by QuoIntelligence
sentence.914: While the DNS-over-HTTPS protocol offers increased privacy and security, it also enables users and threat actors to bypass traditional network controls used to secure a network.
sentence.915: In order for enterprises to make their own switch to DoH, which could introduce a network blind spot, and to prepare for new external threats, a plan must be established.
sentence.916: US Sanctions Against Russia Unlikely to Limit Russian Cyber Espionage
sentence.917: The US recently imposed punitive measures against Russia, including financial sanctions and diplomatic expulsions.
sentence.918: The sanctions are in response to the [SolarWinds espionage campaign](https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2020/12/evasive-attacker-leverages-solarwinds-supply-chain-compromises-with-sunburst-backdoor.html) and Russia’s alleged interference in the 2020 US Presidential elections.
sentence.919: The US sanctioned a total of 32 entities and individuals.
sentence.920: It also set new restrictions on buying Russian sovereign debt and designated six Russian technology companies that support the Russian Intelligence Services’ cyber program.
sentence.921: Moreover, the US will expel ten Russian diplomatic personnel from the US.
sentence.922: The White House stated that it attributes the cyber espionage campaign that exploited SolarWinds to the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) with high confidence.
sentence.923: This campaign, conducted through Russian APT Group *APT29*, compromised approximately nine federal agencies and about 100 private-sector organizations.
sentence.925: To counter Russia’s moves in cyberspace, the White House announced further steps to promote a framework for responsible state behavior in cyberspace.
sentence.926: They also outlined a set of actions to improve US cyber defensive capabilities and resiliency.
sentence.927: Poland and the Czech Republic also expelled Russian diplomats in solidarity with US sanctions.
sentence.928: NATO, the UK, and the EU also joined in, publicly supporting the US.
sentence.929: In turn, Russia continued to deny its involvement in the cyber campaign and retaliated, sanctioning US officials and expelling US, Czech, and Polish diplomats.
sentence.930: While the US previously sanctioned Russia, past sanctions mainly punished election interference and disinformation campaigns.

sentence.932: They also sanctioned Russia for attacks against critical infrastructures, such as the [NotPetya cyberattack](https://techcrunch.com/2020/10/19/justice-department-russian-hackers-notpetya-ukraine/?guccounter=1&guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAFXn--JNuclTXDb9t4x95CjUylGBRD3UKgxstdiu_pgbDM4vc1N6oe_wSrLwGqSbmzwoyYf0Y7ZjYIYmSPY07Mc6odFQCMp9s78gvWrdQiEIWAWW-Lz3pL1Ct2nJeKLL5ljr8SiG_gIYtDHm90O0XyaixAYL4-9TPtIUOXx3VPkU) affecting Ukraine’s power grid back in 2015.

sentence.988: In line with Safari and Firefox, Apple’s model guarantees high transparency on how user data is used and protects user privacy.
sentence.989: Nevertheless, apps like Facebook are lobbying against this new feature because social media platforms primarily rely on this model to survive.
sentence.990: [Facebook has also stressed](https://www.wsj.com/articles/facebook-meets-apple-in-clash-of-the-tech-titanswe-need-to-inflict-pain-11613192406) that these changes will make it harder for small businesses to place targeted ads.
sentence.991: Google’s model is a more gradual and collaborative approach to its privacy changes than what Apple is doing.
sentence.992: Google is consulting with publishers and advertisers and looking for alternatives before phasing third-party cookies out.
sentence.993: However, while Google’s FloCs increase user privacy by targeting groups of people instead of tracking individuals, it is still a form of profiling individuals by creating cohorts.
sentence.994: As such, it is unclear how Google’s new model enhances users’ privacy.
sentence.995: As such, Apple and Google’s innovative approaches will help to strengthen user privacy and will likely shift the way ad tracking and privacy work online.
sentence.996: All these changes could also result in [attackers developing new ways](https://quointelligence.eu/2020/12/cyber-security-trends-in-2021/) to access personally identifiable data online.
sentence.997: E.K.P. & Agent Tesla: The Daily Operations of a Nigerian eCrime Gang
sentence.998: In late 2020, QuoIntelligence identified a malicious Word document.
sentence.999: The Word document contained technical indicators associated with an Agent Tesla malware campaign, a readily available Remote Access Trojan (RAT) that steals keystrokes and credentials.
sentence.1000: It ultimately led us to uncover the operation of a Nigerian eCrime gang.
sentence.1001: Based on our investigation, we dubbed the eCrime gang “E.K.P.”.
sentence.1002: Further, we understand that they are located in Nigeria.
sentence.1003: We also learned that E.K.P is an operator within a service model known as Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS).
sentence.1004: MaaS & RaaS: The All Skill-Level eCrime Conductors
sentence.1005: Cybercriminals are increasingly adopting MaaS for conventional malware campaigns and ransomware deployments (Ransomware-as-a-Service or short RaaS).
sentence.1006: In this report, we highlight the daily operations of E.K.P and the various commodity tools used to both stage and execute attack campaigns.
sentence.1008: The Microsoft Word document that we discovered in 2020 was entitled ”Azerbaijan-Turkey Military Negotiation.doc”.
sentence.1009: Apparently a user from a VirusTotal in the Netherlands containing a weaponized macro uploaded it.
sentence.1010: If the cyber attacker can successfully convince their target to open the document, the kill-chain will be launched, and the malware will be able to steal the information of the person who opened the file.

sentence.1015: E.K.P. Kill-Chain and Tesla Agent’s Connections to Other Malware Families
sentence.1016: The macro embedded with the Word document obfuscates, i.e., creates difficult-to-read code, to another simple obfuscated script.
sentence.1017: This script then tries to download and execute a payload retrieved from a Command and Control (C2) URL.
sentence.1018: However, we determined additional files associated with the same C2 URL: a widespread malware family known as *Agent Tesla*.
sentence.1019: Agent Tesla is a readily available keylogger and Remote Access Trojan (RAT), written in .NET.
sentence.1020: Its primary function includes logging keystrokes and the clipboard to exfiltrate data ultimately.
sentence.1021: At least this specific variant attempts to exfiltrate data from the victim using hardcoded Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) credentials for an attacker-controlled mailbox.
sentence.1022: Another malware family tied to the C2 Infrastructure is “Remcos RAT,” giving a cybercriminal complete control of an infected system.
sentence.1023: Its capabilities include keylogging and surveillance through audio and screenshots.

sentence.1025: Based on what we have learned so far, we dubbed the cybercriminal gang E.K.P, and we understand that they are located in Nigeria.

sentence.1045: Exploit Builder enables E.K.P to create an exploit document (e.g., Microsoft Word or Excel) that delivers a malware payload to a victim host.

sentence.1048: ### Origin Logger (also known as Agent Tesla):
sentence.1049: Through our analysis, we confirm that the payload generated by Origin Logger is nearly the same as previously decoded Agent Tesla payloads.

sentence.1071: Through Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) and other subscription models, less-skilled individuals can execute low-effort cybercrime.

sentence.1074: By 2019, we uncovered [eleven tools attributed to the GC MaaS](https://quointelligence.eu/2021/04/golden-chickens-compilation/)and each customized per campaign for the threat actor purchasing the service.

sentence.1124: CloudFall Targets Researchers and Scientists Invited to International Military Conferences in Central Asia and Eastern Europe
sentence.1125: In August 2021, Zscaler ThreatLabz identified several malicious Microsoft Word documents which used a multi-stage attack-chain abusing Cloudflare Workers and features of MS Office Word to target users in Central Asia and Eastern Europe.
sentence.1126: Based on the social engineering lures used in the decoy content, we conclude with a moderate confidence level that the targets of this campaign were scientists and researchers who were invited to International military conferences.
sentence.1127: We have named this threat actor CloudFall based on the network infrastructure used by them.
sentence.1128: There is also a strong overlap between this threat actor and the CloudAtlas APT group.
sentence.1129: Unlike common macro-based document attacks, in this targeted campaign we observed the threat actor abusing MS Office Word features to evade automated analysis systems.
sentence.1130: There were multiple variants of attack-chains used by this threat actor which highlight the adversary's deep understanding of the MS Office Word application.
sentence.1132: **Attack-chain**: In all the cases, an MS Office Word document was used to download a remote document template and carry out the attack in multiple stages.
sentence.1133: A lot of TTPs in this attack-chain have not been seen before and are unique to the threat actor in this case.
sentence.1134: **Naming conventions of attacker-controlled C2 domains**: We observed a consistent pattern across all the C2 domains used in this targeted campaign.
sentence.1135: All the C2 servers used Cloudflare Worker domains and most of the subdomain names were crafted to spoof Microsoft service names such as Office 365.
sentence.1136: **Regions targeted and content of the decoy files**: Based on the instances we observed in this campaign, the regions targeted were Central Asia and Eastern Europe.
sentence.1137: Based on this, we can say with a moderate confidence level that the threat actor was located in the eastern part of the world.
sentence.1138: By combining all of the above observations, we can say with a moderate confidence level that there is an overlap with CloudAtlas APT threat actor.
sentence.1139: CloudAtlas APT has targeted users in Central Asia and Eastern Europe in the past with documents sent in spear-phishing emails and downloaded remote templates.
sentence.1140: CloudAtlas has also abused legitimate cloud-based services, such as CloudMe, in the past and used domain names that spoof legitimate Microsoft services.
sentence.1141: The tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) are very unique in this instance so we cannot use them to specifically attribute to any threat actor.
sentence.1142: For the document with MD5 hash: 4cf8b660a79fc1b7cc4ea6422a02347d, seen in Figure 1, the cover image is the logo of the German Federal Foreign Office.
sentence.1145: In this campaign, the threat actor used a complex multi-stage attack-chain, which we illustrate in Figure 3.
sentence.1146: Also, it is important to note that there are 2 different variants of attack-chains that we observed for this threat actor.
sentence.1148: The interesting thing to note here is that the attacker doesn’t use the standard DOCX file format (OOXML) for template injection where we have the XML file referencing the document template from a network path.
sentence.1150: Once macros are enabled by the user, the VBA macro code inside the downloaded template is executed.

sentence.1153: **2.** When the document is closed, it checks whether a document template file is present in the path: "%appdata%\Microsoft\Word\STARTUP\Main.dotm".
sentence.1154: It's important to note that the above directory path corresponds to STARTUP location used by Microsoft Office Word application to load global templates.
sentence.1155: The template file is downloaded as base64-encoded data from the URL: "https://cloud.digitalstorage.workers[.]dev/old/data".
sentence.1156: Macro replaces  "$" with "A" and "#" with "Q" in the mangled response before base64-decoding.
sentence.1157: The template file "Main.dotm" acts as a persistence template since it is loaded whenever the Microsoft Word application is started.
sentence.1158: Similar to Stage-2, this is also a macro-based template.
sentence.1159: The malicious macro code is defined under the AutoExit function which is executed when the Microsoft Word application is closed or the global template defining it is unloaded.
sentence.1160: Upon execution, the macro code downloads a base64-encoded binary either from "mirror.advancestore.workers[.]dev/max/bs" or "mirror.advancestore.workers[.]dev/min/bs" based on the checks performed.
sentence.1161: Similar to Stage-2, the base64-encoded binary is mangled and requires character substitution before decoding.
sentence.1162: Once decoded, the macro code drops it as the next stage payload in the path %localappdata%\Photos\Microsoft.Photos.exe and executes it.
sentence.1163: **Note**: The dropped file name spoofs legitimate Windows binary for Microsoft Photos.

sentence.1167: To further hinder the dynamic analysis using debugger, the binary performs self checksum check to detect any attached debugger.
sentence.1169: Executing further, the malicious binary checks for the presence of the file conf.h in the current working directory.

sentence.1189: The second variant of this attack, which we observed in August 2021 made significant changes to the macro code used in the document to deploy the payload on the machine.

sentence.1191: However, unlike variant 1, in this case, the persistence document template as well as the final payload—both are embedded inside the stage-2 document itself.

sentence.1233: Squirrelwaffle: New Loader Delivering Cobalt Strike
sentence.1234: Zscaler ThreatLabz has been following an emerging new malware loader known as Squirrelwaffle that is being used to deliver Cobalt Strike.
sentence.1235: In this blog, we will be analyzing the complete attack chain for this new malware family (as shown in Figure 1).
sentence.1236: The Squirrelwaffle loader is being delivered from the same infrastructure that was delivering the Qakbot banking trojan.
sentence.1239: * The campaign started with a malicious document file delivered via spam email campaigns with embedded URLs.
sentence.1240: * The spam campaign is using an email thread hijacking technique that was previously used for Emotet and Qakbot malware campaigns.
sentence.1241: * The malicious document contains a macro that drops and executes a VBS file in the %ProgramData% folder.
sentence.1242: * The VBS file downloads the Squirrelwaffle loader which in turn downloads another loader which further downloads Cobalt Strike.
sentence.1243: * Newly registered domains are used to host the loader payload.
sentence.1244: * The same infrastructure was used to deliver the Qakbot banking trojan.
sentence.1246: Squirrelwaffle campaigns generally start via spam emails that attempt to convince victims to click an embedded URL using a technique known as email thread hijacking.
sentence.1247: Email thread hijacking leverages emails that have been stolen prior to the attack and later repurposed to dupe a victim into believing that an email is from someone that they know who is replying to the same thread.
sentence.1248: Once a victim clicks on the URL, a ZIP file is downloaded that contains a Microsoft Word document.
sentence.1249: This document is using a DocuSign template lure that instructs the user to enable a macro to view the content (as shown in Figure 2).
sentence.1250: All the other documents analyzed by Zscaler ThreatLabz have exactly the same content with multiple modules that contain VBA code.
sentence.1251: ![Figure 2: Squirrelwaffle Microsoft Word document lure containing a malicious macro](/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto/sites/default/files/images/blogs/Squirrelwaffle/Docusign.PNG)
sentence.1252: Figure 2: Squirrelwaffle Microsoft Word document lure containing a malicious macro
sentence.1253: Once the user enables the macro, an *AutoOpen()* subroutine is called which then executes a malicious Visual Basic Application (VBA) macro.
sentence.1254: There is a UserForm object in the document which contains a VBS file named pin.vbs that is embedded in the caption of the DocuSign image.
sentence.1255: The document that contains the macro code leverages cscript.exe to extract the embedded VBS file, which is written to the %ProgramData% folder, and executed using wscript.exe.
sentence.1256: This VBS file contains an obfuscated PowerShell script with 5 different URLs to download the Squirrelwaffle payload as shown in Figure 3.
sentence.1257: The payload is written to %ProgramData% with the filename ww1.dll.
sentence.1258: ![Figure 3: Example VBA code that drops a VBS file in the %ProgramData% folder that is used to download Squirrelwaffle](/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto/sites/default/files/images/blogs/Squirrelwaffle/Macro%20analysis1.PNG)
sentence.1259: Figure 3: Example VBA code that drops a VBS file in the %ProgramData% folder that is used to download Squirrelwaffle
sentence.1260: The VBS file simply uses the IEX (Invoke-Expression) function to download the Squirrelwaffle loader.
sentence.1261: The payload DLL is executed via rundll32.exe by invoking the export function name *ldr*.
sentence.1262: ![Figure 4: Example VBS code that downloads and executes the Squirrelwaffle loader.](/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto/sites/default/files/images/blogs/Squirrelwaffle/vbs%20file.PNG)
sentence.1263: Figure 4: Example VBS code that downloads and executes the Squirrelwaffle loader.

sentence.1294: Once the malware decodes all of the CnC domains and IP addresses to block, it creates a **socket** and sends the data using the **send()** function and receives the content from the CnC using **recv()** calls.
sentence.1295: The CnC communication protocol utilizes an HTTP POST request with a Base64 encoded payload that is encrypted using an XOR-based algorithm with the hardcoded key ***KJKLO***.
sentence.1296: An example HTTP POST request is shown below:
sentence.1298: Note that this request does not contain a User-Agent field in the HTTP header.
sentence.1299: The path of the HTTP POST request consists of a hardcoded prefix and a Base64 encoded string that is encrypted using the same XOR-based algorithm and key as described above.
sentence.1300: The HTTP POST body contains another Base64 encoded string that includes the victim’s computer name, username, application data directory, and workgroup.

sentence.1302: This payload is also encrypted with the same XOR-based algorithm and key as the HTTP POST path component.
sentence.1303: The SquirrelWaffle CnC responds with a Base64 encoded payload that uses the same encryption schema with another format that uses two tab characters as delimiter between fields.
sentence.1304: The SquirrelWaffle CnC response may also contain a second-stage payload.

sentence.1346: New Trickbot and BazarLoader campaigns use multiple delivery vectors
sentence.1347: The [Zscaler ThreatLabz](https://www.zscaler.com/threatlabz/threat-map-dashboard) research team monitors thousands of files daily tracking new and pervasive threats, including one of the most prominent banking trojans of the last five years: Trickbot.
sentence.1348: Trickbot has been active since 2016 and is linked to a large number of malicious campaigns involving bitcoin mining and theft of banking information, personal identifying information (PII), and credentials.
sentence.1349: BazarLoader is a spinoff of this trojan, developed by the same authors.
sentence.1350: ThreatLabz has discovered Trickbot operators using new approaches to delivering payloads in recent attack campaigns.
sentence.1351: The malware samples we analyzed were well-crafted and highly obfuscated with sandbox-evading capabilities.
sentence.1352: In this blog post, we will show analysis of the different delivery vectors used by Trickbot and BazarLoader.
sentence.1353: 1.Script and LNK files added evasion techniques to leverage Malware threats.
sentence.1354: 2.Multilayer obfuscation is used to preclude analysis of JS and LNK files.
sentence.1355: 3.An Office attachment drops an HTA file with snippets of HTML and javascript functions.
sentence.1356: **Trickbot is expanding its range of file types for malware delivery**
sentence.1357: In previous campaigns, Trickbot payloads were generally dropped as malicious attachments to Microsoft Office files.
sentence.1358: In the last month, we’ve seen that malware has also used javascript files at a high volume, along with a range of other file formats, as shown in the following charts:

sentence.1371: In addition to taking extreme effort to make javascript files highly obfuscated, the malware authors have also added large amounts of junk code to the end to make debugging more difficult.
sentence.1372: The junk code is just random generated obfuscated strings that do not play any role with the malicious code.
sentence.1375: Using the **eval()** function we have de-obfuscated the second layer in which malicious code is embedded with more junk code.
sentence.1376: We can see that the Trickbot authors used the **setTimeout()** method, which evaluates an expression after a 967 milliseconds to delay execution in the sandbox.

sentence.1420: AtomSilo Ransomware Enters the League of Double Extortion
sentence.1421: Ransomware is used widely in cyberattacks to disrupt the victim's organization.
sentence.1422: Over the last two years, many attackers have evolved their ransomware tactics to include data exfiltration.
sentence.1423: This tactic is known as "double-extortion": attackers demand ransom for the data decryption in addition to the ransom to prevent public release of the stolen data.
sentence.1424: ThreatLabz monitors these threat actors and analyzes the attack sequences of double extortion attacks.
sentence.1425: AtomSilo is a new player on the scene, and in this blog, we'll break down the details of their attacks.
sentence.1426: AtomSilo ransomware emerged around September 2021, with their tactics including exfiltrating and publishing their first victim's data.
sentence.1427: We'll break down one of their attacks, which started with initial access through exploiting a vulnerability in [Atlassian’s Confluence collaboration software](https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/10/04/atom-silo-ransomware-actors-use-confluence-exploit-dll-side-load-for-stealthy-attack/).
sentence.1428: The ransomware operators planted a back door using legitimate software via a dll side loading technique.
sentence.1429: The backdoor allowed remote code execution of Windows Shell commands through WMI (Windows Management Interface), which operators exploited using compromised administrative accounts before dropping AtomSilo.
sentence.1430: The AtomSilo payload is 64-bit and packed with a modified UPX packer.
sentence.1431: Once executed, it enumerates each drive and drops a ransom note in each folder except the few listed in *Table1*.
sentence.1434: It enumerates each file and encrypts all folders and files EXCEPT those that contain the below names:
sentence.1439: Ransomware appends  “.atomsilo” extensions to files after encryption.
sentence.1440: Ransomware uses “CreateFileMappingA” and “MapViewOfFile” APIs to map the file in memory and moves the pointer to the start of the mapped file.
sentence.1441: AtomSilo uses XOR and AES Encryption algorithms to encrypt files.
sentence.1442: It generates AES round keys using the “AESKEYGENASSIST”  instruction as shown in the below figure.
sentence.1445: The first 32 bytes are randomly generated by the payload, and other 208 bytes are generated using the “AESKEYGENASSIST” instruction.
sentence.1446: Then, it encrypts it with 14 rounds of AES encryption.
sentence.1449: It encrypts chunks of the file, not the complete file.

sentence.1458: Multilogin is an application designed to make it easier to log into multiple accounts on a single website or platform simultaneously.
sentence.1459: Recently, Zscaler ThreatLabz has come across a live phishing campaign that is targeting genuine Multilogin users by tricking the users into downloading a malicious installer.
sentence.1460: The threat actor has taken great care to match every detail, starting from website layout to the url pattern used for downloading the application, in order to impersonate as the legitimate website.
sentence.1461: The malicious installer installs a stealer (named as multilogin), written in Dotnet, on the compromised machine.
sentence.1462: This stealer gathers sensitive information from the victim's system and sends it to its telegrambot in a zip format.
sentence.1463: The below snapshot shows the delivery mechanism and attack chain of the malware.
sentence.1464: As a first step, the threat actors have cloned the legitimate website, giving it a similar domain name, in order to trick the user into visiting the phishing website and downloading the malicious installer hosted on it.
sentence.1465: Like the normal installer, the malicious installer creates a full environment, starting with registry changes, then creating required folders (explained later), for the effective execution of the malware.
sentence.1466: In order to achieve persistence on the compromised machine, the malicious installer creates a shortcut file in the ***All Users startup folder*** as can be seen in the below snapshot.
sentence.1467: It is to be noted that the installer drops the malware at the user’s selected installation path at the time of installing the application.
sentence.1468: **Required folders:** The installer creates a folder named “**Item”** and the following sub-folders, which shall be checked and used by the malware later:
sentence.1469: * **AutoFills**: Consists of text files containing browser’s autofill information.
sentence.1470: * **Cookies:** Consists of text files containing browser’s cookies information.
sentence.1471: * **IP:** Consists of a text file containing IP address information.
sentence.1472: * **Passwords:** Consists of text files containing user's login information.
sentence.1473: After successful installation, the final GUI (Graphical User Interface) comes up with an enabled check box to launch the application named as multilogin (hereinafter referred to as malware).
sentence.1474: After clicking the “**Finish**” button, the malware comes into play.
sentence.1475: Now, let's get into the code to understand the functionality of the malware.
sentence.1477: Before starting stealing activities, the malware checks the required folders in the system and then executes its functions to collect information from the compromised machine, explained below:
sentence.1478: Firstly, the malware collects the IP address by making a web request to “*checkip.dyndns.org*”and stores the collected information at “**<Installation\_Path>\Item\IPAddress\IPAddress.txt****”,** in the format **<IP\_Address>:<Country\_Name>,** asexplainedin the below snippet**.**
sentence.1479: It is to be noted that the above code also acts as a checkpoint for an internet connection--that is, if the malware doesn’t get a response, then the malware crashes.
sentence.1481: The steps to gather the login data of the user are as follows:

sentence.1483: * The below snippet shows how the SQL query is being executed against the newly created i.e **C:\LoginData0** file to carve out the login information.
sentence.1484: And then the information is decrypted and stored in a new file placed at **<Installation\_Path>\Item\Password\<Browser\_name>Profile\_<Integer>\_PASSWORD.txt>**.
sentence.1485: * The login data contains passwords in an encrypted format, so the malware first gets the key, which shall be used further to decrypt the encrypted password.
sentence.1486: * After getting the key and the encrypted data, the malware will decrypt them by using the below code.

sentence.1493: In the case of Firefox, the malware targets *cookies.sqlite, signons.sqlite* and *logins.json* files to carve out the sensitive information and stores the data in **<Installation\_Path>\Item\cookies\FFProfile\_Cookies.txt** and **<Installation\_Path>\Item\Password\FFProfile\_PASSWORD\_.txt** respectively.
sentence.1494: It is to be noted that for decryption of encrypted data, the malware uses **PK11SDR\_Decrypt**” API of ***nss3.dll***.
sentence.1495: After stealing all the data from different browsers, the malware then creates a zip file which shall be sent to the command and control (C2) server.

sentence.1511: * Two large software supply chain attacks distributed the DanaBot malware.
sentence.1512: * DanaBot is a malware-as-a-service platform discovered in 2018 that focuses on credential theft and banking fraud.
sentence.1513: * DanaBot’s popularity has waned in recent years, but these campaigns may signal a return of the malware and its affiliates to the threat landscape.
sentence.1514: The [DanaBot malware](https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.danabot) had a spike in new activity recently, including being distributed via two large software supply chain attacks and being used in a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack on a Russian language electronics forum.
sentence.1515: DanaBot, [first discovered](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-insight/post/danabot-new-banking-trojan-surfaces-down-under-0) by Proofpoint in May 2018, is a malware-as-a-service platform where threat actors, known as “affiliates” and identified by “affiliate IDs”, purchase access to the platform from another threat actor who develops the malware and [command and control (C2) panel](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-insight/post/danabot-control-panel-revealed), sets up and maintains the shared C2 infrastructure, and provides sales and customer support.
sentence.1516: Affiliates then distribute and use the malware as they see fit--mostly to steal credentials and commit banking fraud.
sentence.1517: While it was a prominent banking malware for a number of years and despite a new major update being spotted at the end of 2020 (as documented by [Proofpoint](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/new-year-new-version-danabot), [ESET](https://twitter.com/ESETresearch/status/1420734522581295106), and [LEXFO](https://blog.lexfo.fr/danabot-malware.html)), DanaBot has been relatively quiet in the recent threat landscape.
sentence.1519: As reported by the [Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA)](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/current-activity/2021/10/22/malware-discovered-popular-npm-package-ua-parser-js), [GitHub](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-pjwm-rvh2-c87w), [the developer](https://github.com/faisalman/ua-parser-js/issues/536), and others the NPM JavaScript package for “UAParser.js” was compromised on Friday, October 22, 2021 and used to distribute a cryptocurrency miner and DanaBot.
sentence.1520: [UAParser.js](https://www.npmjs.com/package/ua-parser-js) is a “JavaScript library to detect Browser, Engine, OS, CPU, and Device type/model from User-Agent data with relatively small footprint.
sentence.1521: The DanaBot malware was downloaded from:
sentence.1522: *Figure 1: DanaBot malware configuration used in supply chain attack*
sentence.1523: The malware was also configured with a backup TOR C2:
sentence.1524: Based on Zscaler ThreatLabz tracking, this is a new affiliate to the DanaBot ecosystem.
sentence.1525: At the time of the incident, the affiliate had only configured the malware’s credential stealing component to be active--the person-in-the-browser and webinject bank fraud component was not activated.
sentence.1526: While the post-infection intentions of the threat actor aren’t known, given the focus on credentials, the size of the attack, and the crimeware landscape being dominated by initial access brokers selling access to ransomware affiliates, this outcome can’t be ruled out.
sentence.1528: As reported by [Twitter](https://twitter.com/nonattributable/status/1456255408201338881), [GitHub](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-73qr-pfmq-6rp8), and [others](https://github.com/veged/coa/issues/99), another NPM package was compromised and used to distribute DanaBot.
sentence.1529: The attack took place on  Thursday, November 4, 2021 and it was by the same DanaBot affiliate ID 40 threat actor as in the October 22, 2021 attack on “UAParser.js”.

sentence.1532: Similar to the first incident, the threat actor had only configured the malware’s credential stealing component to be active.
sentence.1533: **DDoS Attack on Russian Language Electronics Forum**
sentence.1534: DanaBot affiliate ID 4 was also active last week.
sentence.1535: On Wednesday October 20, 2021, the affiliate configured its DanaBot victims to download and execute a new executable with a SHA-256 hash of:
sentence.1536: The downloaded executable is written in the Delphi programming language and its only functionality is to implement a bare-bones HTTP-based DDoS attack on a hardcoded IP address and host.
sentence.1537: The template used to generate the HTTP requests is shown in Figure 2:
sentence.1538: *Figure 2: HTTP request template used in DDoS attack*
sentence.1539: As highlighted in the “Host” header in Figure 2 above, the attack targets a Russian language forum focused on the discussion of electronics.
sentence.1540: The “User-Agent” header, hardcoded target, and simple functionality seems to imply that the payload was designed to settle a personal grudge instead of indicating a larger change in the threat actor’s tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs).
sentence.1541: While the popularity and activity of DanaBot has declined in recent years, the UAParser.js and COA software supply chain attacks shows that the malware is still an active threat.
sentence.1542: It is currently unclear whether these attacks were a one-off opportunity for a threat actor or whether this and other activity signals the return of DanaBot and its affiliates.

sentence.1565: * Emotet is one of the most dangerous, prolific, and long-lasting malware Trojans that has ever existed.
sentence.1566: * In January 2021, a law enforcement action disrupted the Emotet malware and its infrastructure.
sentence.1567: It also led to the arrest of some of the threat actors involved with the malware.
sentence.1568: * After almost a year-long hiatus, Emotet has returned to the threat landscape as of Nov 14, 2021.
sentence.1569: * Distribution of the malware was via the TrickBot malware and email campaigns.
sentence.1570: After an almost year-long hiatus, the prolific malware [Emotet](https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/emotet-back-action-after-short-break) has returned to the threat landscape.
sentence.1571: An [early report](https://cyber.wtf/2021/11/15/guess-whos-back/) indicated it returned on Sunday November 14, 2021 and it was being distributed via the [TrickBot](https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/new-trickbot-and-bazarloader-campaigns-use-multiple-delivery-vectors) botnet.
sentence.1572: A [later report](https://isc.sans.edu/diary/28044) indicated that it was also being distributed via email campaigns.
sentence.1573: The Emotet malware was first detected back in 2014 and it focused on banking fraud.
sentence.1574: In recent years, Emotet pivoted and it became an initial access broker providing victim access for several ransomware groups.
sentence.1575: In January 2021, [law enforcement](https://www.europol.europa.eu/newsroom/news/world%E2%80%99s-most-dangerous-malware-emotet-disrupted-through-global-action) disrupted the Emotet malware and its infrastructure.
sentence.1576: It also arrested some of the threat actors behind it.
sentence.1577: This led to the disappearance of the malware for almost a year.
sentence.1578: While the Threatlabz team's technical analysis for the payloads involved is ongoing, the new version of the Emotet malware is similar to its past variants in many aspects.
sentence.1579: In our quick analysis, we've observed some changes in the command and control data and encryption used.
sentence.1580: It also appears to be using HTTPS instead of  plain HTTP for command and control communication.
sentence.1581: It looks like most of the functionality is the same as earlier variants, and it will likely pick up where it left off, providing initial access to the ransomware operators.
sentence.1582: As we can see from the below screenshot of spam email, Emotet starts by leveraging a 'reply chain' email strategy in their spam campaigns.
sentence.1583: It has been using MS word document “.docm”, MS excel “.xlsm” and password protected “.zip” files as attachments.
